Tuning the product distribution by changing the acid properties of the catalysts Priscilla Magalhães de Souza Conceptualization Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a Leandro Alves de Sousa Conceptualization Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a Fábio Bellot Noronha Data curation Supervision Writing – review & editing a b Robert Wojcieszak Conceptualization Visualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration a ⁎ a UMR 8181 – UCCS – Unité de Catalyse et Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Lille, Centrale Lille, Université Artois, Lille 59000, France UMR 8181 – UCCS – Unité de Catalyse et Chimie du Solide CNRS Université de Lille Centrale Lille Université Artois Lille 59000 France aUMR 8181 – UCCS – Unité de Catalyse et Chimie du Solide, CNRS, Université de Lille, Centrale Lille, Université Artois, Lille 59000, France b Catalysis, Biocatalysis and Chemical Processes Division, National Institute of Technology, Rio de Janeiro, RJ 20081-312, Brazil Catalysis, Biocatalysis and Chemical Processes Division National Institute of Technology Rio de Janeiro RJ 20081-312 Brazil bCatalysis, Biocatalysis and Chemical Processes Division, National Institute of Technology, Rio de Janeiro, RJ 20081-312, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. The effect of the catalytic properties of various types of solid acids, including oxides (ZrO2, SOX/ZrO2, WOX/ZrO2, Nb2O5, NbOPO4, Al2O3, TiO2), silica–aluminas (ZSM5 and USY zeolites) and acidic ion-exchange resins (Amberlyst-70 and Dowex 50wx8) were investigated for liquid-phase levoglucosan (LGA) conversion. H2SO4 was also evaluated as a reference catalyst. The concentration of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the catalysts was measured by FTIR of adsorbed pyridine and titration with NaOH. The catalysts were tested under different reaction conditions (110–170 °C and 30–60 bar of N2) for 1 h using tetrahydrofuran (THF) as solvent. The product distribution obtained from the LGA conversion can be tuned depending on the type of acid site of the catalyst or the reaction conditions used. Catalysts containing only Bronsted acid sites were selective to LA while those with both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites favored the formation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). LGO was mainly produced by the homogeneous catalyst. The USY and HZM5 (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 23) promoted the production of HMF and glucose, respectively. A reaction mechanism was proposed taking into account the acid properties of the catalysts. The reactions of dehydration of LGA to LGO or hydration of glucose requires Brønsted acid sites. Catalysts with only Lewis acid sites produced only humins. For the catalysts containing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, LGA is mainly hydrated to glucose on the Bronsted acid sites. Then, glucose is preferentially isomerized to fructose on the Lewis acid sites, followed by its dehydration to HMF. The low LA formation shows that the hydration of HMF to LA requires a higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Levoglucosan Levoglucosenone Acid catalysts Dehydration Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignocellulosic biomass has great potential to be used as a source for the sustainable production of fuels and chemicals [1]. Currently, the carbohydrate fractions of lignocellulosic biomass (cellulose and hemicellulose) are commercially used, but their application is limited to textiles and paper manufacturing. Recently, cellulose has received increasing attention as a potential feedstock for the production of chemicals and fuels [2]. Different technologies have been investigated for the conversion of cellulose into high-value chemicals [3,4]. The primary thermochemical technology for the conversion of cellulose into chemicals is fast pyrolysis, which produces mainly levoglucosan (1,6-anhydro-b-D-glucopyranose) in yields of up to 60% [5]. Levoglucosan (LGA) is a promising platform molecule that can be used in the manufacture of plastics, surfactants, pharmaceuticals, propellants and resins [5–7]. LGA can be converted into a myriad of compounds among them, levoglucosenone (LGO) has attracted special attention. LGO (1,6-anhydro-3,4-dideoxy-β-D-glycero-hex-3-enopyranos-2-ulose) is a highly functionalized molecule due to its carbonyl and olefinic bonds and the anhydro bridge, which makes it very reactive (acid and base-catalyzed reactions, Michael addition, cycloaddition reactions, Baeyer-Villiger oxidation reaction). Depending on the process conditions, each of these groups can react selectively [8–10]. In addition, LGO has two chiral centers at C1 and C5 atoms. Therefore, LGO has been intensively used as a chiral building block for the synthesis of a wide variety of compounds, some of them biologically active products used for the synthesis of anti-cancer drugs, antibiotics precursors, antiviral, antibacterial, as well as natural products [8–10]. For instance, indinavir, a highly active protease inhibitor developed for the treatment of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, can be synthesized using LGO [11]. LGO has also been used in the synthesis of various chemical intermediates and platform molecules with industrial applications [12–14]: (i) 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) that can be used for the synthesis of a wide variety of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, fuels, and fuel additives [15]; (ii) dihydrolevoglucosenone, a polar aprotic solvent (Cyrene) [16]; (iii) 1,6-hexanediol, widely used in the polymer industry for the production of polyesters and polyurethane resins [17,18] that can also be transformed into adipic acid and caprolactam, which are used for the manufacturing of polymers such as nylon 66 and nylon 6, both commonly used in the fiber and textile industries [19,20]. LGO may be produced by the catalytic dehydration of LGA. However, only a few works studied the catalytic conversion of LGA into LGO in the liquid phase [21–24]. Cao et al. [21] and He et al. [22] studied the conversion of cellulose to LGO and HMF with different homogeneous catalysts (H2SO4, H3PO4, HCl, HCOOH) and solvents (polar protic and aprotic). One of the highest yields of LGO was obtained using THF as the solvent, while water, ethanol [21] and DMSO [22] did not produce LGO or led to very low yields of LGO. The dehydration of LGA to LGO using H2SO4 with THF and THF/water mixture under different temperatures (170 and 190 °C) at 69 bar was also investigated. LGO (31.5% yield) and HMF (5.5% yield) were the main products formed, with trace amounts of furfural at 170 °C. The addition of water decreased the LGO yield (25%) and significantly increased the HMF yield (20%). Glucose (7% yield) and furfural (2% yield) were formed as well. Increasing the reaction temperature to 190 °C further increased the formation of LGO which achieved 49% yield, while the production of HMF remained unchanged (6% yield). However, the addition of water significantly affected the LGO yield which dropped to 22% and increased the HMF yield (28%). Glucose was also formed. Regardless of the reaction conditions, both soluble and insoluble humins were observed. A reaction mechanism was proposed to explain the formation of different products. Recently, the same group studied the dehydration of LGA to LGO in THF at 210 °C using solid Brønsted acid functionalized silica catalysts (synthesized propyl sulfonic-functionalized mesoporous silica and commercial acid-functionalized non-ordered porous silica -SiliaBond) [23]. The solid acid catalysts exhibited higher LGA conversion (100%) than the homogeneous catalysts (around 50%). At the same LGA conversion (50%), propylsulfonic acid functionalized catalysts showed higher LGO selectivities (around 45–52%) than homogeneous catalysts (around 33%). The conversion of levoglucosan was investigated using Amberlyst 70 as the catalyst and different solvents such as mono-alcohols, poly-alcohols, water and mixtures, acetone and dimethyl sulfoxide at 170 °C and autogenous pressure [24]. Levulinic acid was the main product formed with water and alcohol mixtures, except for the ethanol/water. In this case, a significant formation of ethyl levulinate was observed. Ethyl glucopyranosides were also formed with ethanol. DMSO, a polar aprotic solvent, favored the formation of HMF, but the authors commented that LGO was also produced. Huang et al. [25] studied the conversion of LGA (0.1 M) in DMSO (140 °C, 12 h) using different catalysts: Amberlyst 70, Nafion NR 50, sulfonated carbon, and Modernite, Beta, ZSM5 and Y zeolites. Resin catalysts were more active, and the highest yield to LGO was achieved with Amberlyst 70. According to the authors, LGA was dehydrated and isomerized to LGO and 1,6-Anhydro-β-D-glucofuranose (AGF), respectively. LGA was also converted to glucose by hydrolysis consuming water generated in the dehydration of LGA, and HMF was produced from both, LGO and glucose. Excepted for the work of Oyola-Rivera et al. [23], Hu et al. [24] and Huang et al. [25], who used propylsulfonic acid functionalized silica, cation exchange resins and zeolites, most of the studies investigated the dehydration of LGA to LGO using homogeneous catalysts. Therefore, the goal of this work is to study the performance of solid acid catalysts with different acid properties (oxides = ZrO2, SOX/ZrO2, WOX/ZrO2, Nb2O5, NbOPO4, Al2O3, TiO2; zeolites = ZSM5 and USY; and resins = Amberlyst-70 and Dowex 50wx8) for the dehydration of LGA to LGO. The effect of the reaction conditions (temperature, pressure) on product distribution was also evaluated. The different reaction pathways were correlated with the acid properties of the catalysts, which gives insights into the design of optimum catalysts for the production of LGO from LGA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts Catalysts with different acid properties (Lewis and Brønsted acid sites) were investigated for the LGA dehydration reaction. The following commercial catalysts were tested: H2SO4 (Sigma Aldrich), Amberlyst 70 (Rohm and Haas), Dowex 50wx8 (Sigma Aldrich), monoclinic (m-ZrO2) and tetragonal (t-ZrO2) zirconia (Saint Gobain), SOX/ZrO2 (MEL Chemicals, XZO 1720/01), WOX/ZrO2 (MEL Chemicals, XZO 1251/02), NbOPO4 (CBMM), Al2O3 (Puralox NWa155), TiO2 (P25, Sigma Aldrich), ZSM5 (Zeolyst, CBV 2314, CBV 5525, CBV 28014 with SiO2/Al2O3 = 23, 55 and 280), USY (Zeolyst, CBV 760, SiO2/Al2O3 = 60). Nb2O5 was synthesized by calcination of niobic acid (CBMM) under static air at 400 °C (5 °C min−1) for 4 h. The SOX/ZrO2 and WOX/ZrO2 were also previously calcined under static air at different conditions (SOX/ZrO2=at 500 °C, 5 °C min−1 for 1 h; WOX/ZrO2=at 750 °C, 10 °C min−1 for 1 h). The zeolite samples were converted to proton form via thermal treatment at 2 steps under N2 flow (50 mL min−1): heating from room temperature to 150 °C for 1 h, and then, rising to 500 °C for 4.5 h. On both steps, the heating rate was 5 °C min−1. The following nomenclature was adopted for the zeolites: HZM5 (23), HZM5 (55), HZM5 (280) and USY (60). The numbers in parentheses indicates the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface areas of the samples were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer by N2 adsorption at 77 K. The samples were treated at 623 K until reach a 9 mmHg vacuum for degassing and remove the adsorbed species. The specific areas were calculated from the Brunnauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a D8 Advance instrument from Brucker, equipped with a Cukα X-ray source (λ = 1.5418 Å), using the following parameters: 2θ range between 5 and 40°, scan rate of 0.02°/step, and acquisition time of 1 s/step. The surface acid properties of the catalysts were characterized by different methods: FTIR of adsorbed pyridine (gas phase) and titration method (aqueous phase). The type of acid sites was determined by FTIR of pyridine. The Fourier infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet Protege 460 instrument equipped with a CSi beam splitter and a MCT detector with a 2 cm−1 resolution. Before the analysis, the samples were pressed into a self-supported wafer (2.01 cm2) and placed in a quartz cell equipped with KBr windows. Samples were dried under a high vacuum (P < 10−7 mbar) at 450 °C overnight. Pyridine was then adsorbed at 100 °C until achieving equilibrium and the samples were evacuated at 150 °C under a high vacuum (P < 10−7 mbar) for 30 min before spectra acquisition. The bands located at 1450 and 1540 cm−1 were used for the quantification of the coordinated Pyridine to Lewis (εL = 2.22 cm/µmol) and Brønsted (εB = 1.67 cm/µmol) acid sites, respectively, according to the Beer-Lambert law. For the aqueous phase titration method (quantification of Brønsted acid sites) [26], 50 mg of catalyst powder was treated with 20 ml of a 1.0 M aqueous solution of NaCl for 1 h at room temperature under sonication. After the centrifugal separation, the supernatant solution was titrated with a 0.01 M aqueous solution of NaOH using phenolphthalein as the neutralization indicator. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted to confirm the presence of carbonaceous compounds on the used catalyst. TG profiles were obtained using a TA-Instruments Q600 SDT under pure O2 flow (50 mL/min). The used catalyst (∼10 mg) was heated from ambient temperature to 800 °C at 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic performance The catalytic screening reactions were performed using the Freeslate MultiReactor from Unchained Laboratories available on the EQUIPEX high-throughput platform REALCAT at École Centrale de Lille. It consists of 24 parallel batch reactors (volume of 6 mL), in which each reactor was loaded with LGA (Acros Organics, 99%) solution (1.5 mL, 0.05 mol/L) in tetrahydrofuran (THF - Sigma-Aldrich, anhydrous, > 99.9%, inhibitor-free), and the acid catalysts (10–60 mg). The following catalysts were tested: H2SO4, Amberlyst 70, Dowex 50wx8, ZrO2, SOX/ZrO2, WOX/ZrO2, Nb2O5, NbOPO4, Al2O3, TiO2, USY (SiO2/Al2O3 = 60), HZSM5 (SiO2/Al2O3 = 23, 55, 280). The reaction was carried out at 150 °C, under 30 bar of N2, at 600 rpm for 1 h. Tests at different temperatures (110, 150 and 170 °C) and pressures (30 and 60 bar) were carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave (model 2456 0000, Top Industrie, Fr) with a maximum internal volume of 30 mL using H2SO4, Amberlyst70 and WOX/ZrO2 catalysts. The autoclave was equipped with a heating system, mechanical stirring, cooling bath and it was operated in batch conditions (linked with a pure N2 tank). All experiments were performed in the absence of diffusional limitations (internal and external) and in a kinetic regime. The internal limitation was avoided by sieving all materials at 150 and 270 mesh. And the external limitation was discarded from the catalytic tests carried out with the same catalyst mass and 3 different agitation speeds (400, 600 and 800 rpm). No significant differences in terms of conversion and product yields were observed in the three cases. Then, all experiments were performed with a stirring speed of 600 rpm. Blank tests with pure solvent (THF) and LGA were also carried out to assess possible thermal degradation of the solvent or LGA. To investigate the mechanism of LGA conversion, further catalytic tests using intermediate molecules (glucose, HMF, LGO) were also done. The best experimental conditions for LGO production were applied for the conversion of LGA obtained by cellulose fast pyrolysis [27]. For all experiments, the liquid products were separated from the catalyst by filtration with a 0.22 μm PTFE membrane filter and then analyzed by gas chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry (GC/MS) and flame ionization detector (GC/FID), and by High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC). The GC/FID and GC/MS (Agilent Technologies 7890B) were equipped with a CP-Wax 52 CB column. The HPLC (Shimadzu) was equipped with RI and UV detectors and a Rezex ROA-Organic Acid column, using diluted sulfuric acid (5 mM, 0.6 mL/min) as a mobile phase. The compounds were quantified with calibration curves using standard samples (glucose, fructose, formic acid by HPLC; and furfural, LGA, LGO, HMF, LA by GC-FID) while unavailability commercial compounds such as 1,4:3,6-dianhydro-α-D-glucopyranose (DGP) and ethyl-glucopyranoside (EGP) were quantified using the calibration curve of LGA from the FID. The yield and distribution of detectable products were calculated on a carbon basis (%-C). The conversion of LGA (XLGA), product distribution (PD), product yield (Y) and carbon balance (CB) were calculated using Eqs. (1), (2), (3), and (4), respectively. (1) X L G A ( % ) = [ m m o l L G A ] 0 − [ m m o l L G A ] t [ m m o l L G A ] 0 x 100 (2) P D ( % ) = [ m m o l c o m p o u n d ] ∑ [ m m o l p r o d u c t s ] x 100 (3) Y ( % ) = [ m m o l c o m p o u n d ] [ m m o l L G A ] 0 x C C o m p o u n d C L G A (4) C B ( % ) = ( ∑ i = 0 n Y i + [ m m o l L G A ] t [ m m o l L G A ] 0 ) x 100 where 0 corresponds to the beginning of the reaction and t at any time; n is the total number of products, and C is the number of carbons in the molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The diffractograms of all commercial catalysts (except for Amberlyst 70 and Dowex50wx8) are presented in Fig. S1. The diffractograms of Nb2O5 and NbOPO4 exhibited a broad peak around 2θ = 25° corresponding to the amorphous niobia phase [28]. The diffractogram of Al2O3 showed diffraction lines corresponding to γ− Al2O3 (2θ€= 37.4; 39.4; 46.0; 60.7; 66.9; JCPD: 04-0880). For the TiO2 catalyst, the diffractogram showed the lines corresponding to both anatase (JCPD: 21-1272) and rutile (JCPD: 21-1276) phase of titania. The diffractogram of m-ZrO2 displayed the characteristic lines of the monoclinic zirconia phase (JCPD 37-1484) while the diffractograms of t-ZrO2, SOx/ZrO2 and WOx/ZrO2 showed the lines corresponding to tetragonal zirconia phase (JCPD 17-0923). For the t-ZrO2 and WOx/ZrO2, peaks with low intensity were observed at 24.4 and 28.1° indicating the presence of the monoclinic phase. All ZSM5 and USY zeolites exhibited peaks characteristics of MFI structure (JCPD: 42-0024) and FAU (JCPD: 77-1549) structures. Table 1 lists the surface areas and the number of acid sites determined FTIR of pyridine and aqueous phase titration for all catalysts. The N2 adsorption and FTIR of adsorbed pyridine were not carried out for Amberlyst 70 and Dowex50wx8 due to the lower thermal stability of these materials (190 °C for Amberlyst 70 and 150 °C for Dowex50W8X). Among the catalysts, WOX/ZrO2 and TiO2 exhibited the smallest specific surface areas (85 and 42 m2/g, respectively), while the highest ones were observed for HZSM5 and USY zeolites (HZSM5 = 400–432 m2/g, USY = 863 m2/g). The nature of acid sites was studied by FTIR of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. S2) and the bands at 1540 and 1450 cm−1 were associated with pyridine coordinated to Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively. The FTIR spectra for adsorption of pyridine on TiO2, Al2O3 and m-ZrO2 samples revealed only the presence of Lewis acid sites while for the other samples, the bands corresponding to Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were observed. The Brønsted to Lewis acid sites ratio measured by FTIR of pyridine adsorbed decreased in the following order (μmol/gcat): HZSM5 (55) (302.0) >> HZSM5 (280) (18.3) > HZSM5 (23) (4.0) > USY (1.0) > t-ZrO2 ∼ SOx/ZrO2 (0.5) > NbOPO4∼Nb2O5 (0.3) > WOx/ZrO2 (0.2) > m-ZrO2 ≈ Al2O3 ≈ TiO2 (0.0). The acidity of catalysts was also determined in an aqueous solution by titration with NaOH. This method quantifies only the Brønsted acid sites through the measurement of free protons in solution due to the initial cation exchange between the catalyst surface and a salt, in this case, NaCl (catalyst + aqueous NaCl solution, sonication for 1 h). The acidity measured by titration with NaOH followed the order (μmol/gcat): Dowex50W8X (6074) > Amberlyst 70 (2978) ≫ HZSM5 (23) (668) > SOx/ZrO2 (605) > NbOPO4 (538) > t-ZrO2 (471) > HZSM5 (55) (358) > Nb2O5 (268) > USY (234) > HZSM5 (280) (152) > WOx/ZrO2 (106) > m-ZrO2 ≈ Al2O3 ≈ TiO2 (21). The acidity values found for the resins are close to those reported by Guilera et al. [29] who also quantified the acidity by titration against the standard base (Dowex50W8X = 4830 μmol/gcat; Amberlyst 70 = 2650 μmol/gcat). Furthermore, the acidity of HZSM5 samples with different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios determined by the two techniques are in agreement and shows that the increase in framework aluminum content (decrease of SiO2/Al2O3 ratios) increases the number of total acid sites. 3.2 Dehydration of LGA Initially, the dehydration of LGA was studied at 150 °C and 30 bar of N2 for 1 h using THF as solvent. Preliminary blank tests were carried out with pure solvent (THF) and LGA solution (0.05 M) without catalyst, and with THF in the presence of different catalysts (H2SO4, Amberlyst 70 and WOX/ZrO2). No thermal degradation of THF or LGA was observed since no products were detected in the tests with THF or LGA without catalysts. THF reacted in the presence of catalysts and different products were formed depending on the catalyst: γ-butyrolactone was the main product using H2SO4 and 1,4-butanediol was mainly produced over Amberlyst 70 and WOx/ZrO2 among other compounds formed by alcohol condensation reaction. The chromatograms for acid-catalyzed degradation reaction of THF are shown in Fig. S3. The scheme of the degradation reactions of solvent is shown in Fig. S4. These results suggest that even under an inert atmosphere (30 bar N2), THF may be converted to γ-butyrolactone, which was sequentially converted to 1,4 butanediol via ring-opening reaction [30]. Solid catalysts with different acid properties were screened for the dehydration of LGA at 150 °C and 30 bar for 1 h. H2SO4 was used for comparison with heterogeneous catalysts because it has been largely studied in the literature. The concentration of sulfuric acid was chosen to have the same level of acidity as Amberlyst 70 (H+ = 53 mM). The LGA conversion and distribution of products for the catalysts that were active for dehydration of LGA are reported in Fig. 1. In general, conversion close to 100% was achieved for H2SO4, Amberlyst, Dowex, t-ZrO2, WOx/ZrO2 and USY. SOx/ZrO2, and NbOPO4 exhibited 83 and 60% of LGA conversion, respectively. The HZSM5 zeolites presented low conversion: 39% for HZSM5 (23); 20% for HZSM5 (55); and 3% for HZSM5 (280)). Only the result obtained for HZSM5 (23) was added in Fig. 1 for comparison with the other catalysts. The catalysts containing only Lewis acid sites (Al2O3, TiO2, and m-ZrO2) or low concentration of Bronsted acid sites (Nb2O5) exhibited low activity for dehydration of LGA (conversion < 15%). Furthermore, no products were detected, indicating that the formation of humins was favored for the direct conversion of LGA in the presence of a Lewis acid site. The activity seems to be related to the amount of Bronsted acid sites. The catalysts containing only Bronsted acid sites as well as the ones with a high amount of Bronsted acid sites exhibited higher LGA conversion, except for HZSM5 and WOx/ZrO2 catalysts. For the HZSM5 catalysts, in addition to the acidic properties (Bronsted and Lewis acid sites), the diffusivity of reagents and products through the channels of zeolites may also affect LGA conversion. For instance, HZSM5(23) exhibited lower conversion than both resins (Amberlyst 70 and Dowex 50wx8) despite its elevated acidity. This is likely due to the diffusion limitations of the LGA molecule through the micropores of the zeolite. Huang et al. [25] also reported lower activity of zeolites (Mordenite, Beta, ZSM-5 and Y) than for resins (Amberlyst 70 and Nafion NR50) reinforcing that for the resins, the LGA molecule has free access to the active sites. The comparison between the results obtained for the HZM5 and USY zeolites shows that the catalytic performance is affected by the amount of acid sites, which directly depends on the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of the framework (the higher SiO2/Al2O3 ratios show a lower amount of Brønsted acid sites) as well as the porosity of the zeolites, which influence the diffusion of reactants. ZSM5 and USY are zeolites with different shapes and pore sizes. The structure of HZSM5 consists of two types of pores (straight channels with pore sizes of 0.53 nm × 0.56 nm and cross-linked sinusoidal channels of 0.51 nm × 0.55 nm), while USY has a faujasite three-dimensional structure with the pore size determined by the 12-ring of oxygen atoms (0.74 nm) [31]. This suggests that LGA and some products can diffuse easier through the USY zeolite pores than ZSM5 pores. According to kinetic diameters estimated for glucose (0.86 nm), HMF (0.62 nm) and LGA (0.67 nm) [32], we can suggest that these compounds will be formed at the external surface sites in the case of HZSM5. For USY zeolite, the internal diffusion of HMF and LGA may occur, which could be responsible for the higher LGA conversion on USY than for HZSM5. In the case of WOx/ZrO2 catalyst, its high activity is likely due to the lower amount of Lewis acid sites, which leads to the lower formation of humins and consequently, lower deactivation than the other catalysts. LGO, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), furfural, glucose, levulinic acid (LA) and formic acid (FA) were the main products formed from LGA conversion. In addition, products stemming from THF decomposition were also observed but they were not considered. However, a remarkable difference in product distribution was observed depending on the catalyst as shown in Fig. 1. LGO (68%) and glucose (27%) were the only products formed in the presence of H2SO4. Concerning the solid acid catalysts, Amberlyst 70 and Dowex 50wx8 exhibited the same product distribution, with LA (44%) as the main product and lower amounts of FA (20%), furfural (15%), HMF (15%), and LGO (5%). Despite containing only Brønsted acid sites, these resins did not promote the formation of LGO as the homogeneous catalyst. USY, t-ZrO2, SOx/ZrO2, WOx/ZrO2 and NbOPO4 showed a high formation of HMF. The highest selectivity to HMF was obtained for USY, while WOx/ZrO2 showed the second highest formation of LGO after H2SO4. Glucose and furfural were the main products formed for HZM5 with a SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 23. These results reveal that product distribution is also strongly affected by the acid properties of the catalysts. Catalysts containing only Bronsted acid sites were selective to LA while those with both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites favored the formation of HMF. LGO was formed in significant amounts only for WOX/ZrO2. Based on this preliminary screening, the effect of temperature, pressure and conversion on products distribution was investigated for H2SO4, Amberlyst 70 and WOX/ZrO2 catalysts. H2SO4 and WOX/ZrO2 exhibited the highest LGO yield. Amberlyst 70 was chosen because this catalyst contains only Brønsted acid sites, which allows a direct comparison with the homogeneous catalyst. 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst loading Fig. 2 shows product distribution as a function of LGA conversion over Amberlyst 70 and WOX/ZrO2. For Amberlyst 70 (Fig. 2A), increasing the conversion strongly decreased the selectivity to LGO (from 49 to 6%) and glucose (16 to 2%), whereas the selectivity to LA increased from 14 to 43% and 0 to 17%, respectively. The selectivity to HMF and furfural remained approximately constant. Therefore, the increase in LGA conversion promoted the formation of LA as well as humins because the CB decreased. The marked reduction in LGO formation is likely due to its polymerization to form humins, or its conversion to HMF, which is rapidly converted to LA and formic acid. Thus, at higher conversions, LA appears as the main product. On the contrary, for WOX/ZrO2 catalyst, increasing the conversion up to 73% increased the selectivity to LGO, HMF, furfural and LA whereas the selectivity to glucose decreased. Further increase in the LGA conversion did not affect the selectivities to LGO and HMF that remained constant. However, the selectivity to glucose decreased while the formation of furfural increased. At high LGA conversion (96%), the maximum LGO selectivity (36%) was achieved and a slight drop in HMF concentration was observed due to the sequential formation of LA. For both catalysts it appears that the formation of LGO and HMF takes place by parallel routes, however, the formation of LA from HMF is less favored over WOX/ZrO2 compared to Amberlyst 70. It is important to notice that FA should be formed with the same concentration of LA (1:1), however, the lower concentration of formic acid indicates possible parallel reactions even with the solvent. 3.2.2 Effect of reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature (110, 150 and 170 °C) on LGA conversion is shown in Fig. 3. The complete conversion of LGA was obtained for H2SO4 and WOX/ZrO2, regardless of the reaction temperature. For Amberlyst, the LGA conversion was 47% at 100 °C and increased to almost full conversion at high temperature. For H2SO4 (Fig. 3A), glucose, LGO and fructose were the main products formed at 110 °C. The increase in the temperature from 110 to 170 °C increased the amount of LGO from 31 to 87%, while glucose and fructose were no longer detected. For Amberlyst 70 (Fig. 3B), the major products at 110 °C were glucose (47%), ethyl-glucopyranosides isomers (EGP; 23%), and HMF (16%). The formation of EGP isomers is possible by sequential hydrolysis of LGA (1,6 anhydride ring) and esterification reactions with compounds formed by the decomposition of THF solvent. Increasing temperature to 150 °C, the amount of HMF (22%) increased, and a significant formation of LA (28%) and LGO (25%) is now observed, while the selectivity to glucose strongly decreased (7%). Further increase in the reaction temperature to 170 °C led to an additional increase in the selectivity to LA and LGO. The dehydration of LGA at 110 °C over WOX/ZrO2 catalyst produced mainly EGP isomers (71%) and fructose (14%). Increasing the temperature, the EGP isomers were no longer detected and the main products formed at 170 °C were LGO (63%) and furfural (25%). 3.2.3 Effect of reaction pressure The effect of N2 pression (30 and 60 bar) on LGA conversion was also evaluated at 170 °C (Fig. 4). In all cases, the carbon balance increased with the N2 pression and it was more pronounced over H2SO4. For H2SO4, the amount of LGO slightly increased from 87% (30 bar) to 93% (60 bar). For Amberlyst 70, the increase in pressure slightly increased the production of LA and HMF, whereas LGO formation was strongly inhibited. For WOX/ZrO2 catalyst, the increase in pressure promoted mainly the formation of HMF (from 5 to 20%), while the production of furfural and LGO (62.5–54.0) slightly decreased. The conversion of LGA extracted from cellulose pyrolysis bio-oil (designed as LGA Bio) was also evaluated for H2SO4, Amberlyst 70 and WOX/ZrO2 (Fig. 4) at 170 °C, 60 bar of N2. For H2SO4 and WOx/ZrO2 catalysts, the selectivity to LGO decreased and the formation of HMF and furfural increased. This result suggests that the presence of some compounds in the bio-oil undetectable by GC and HPLC such as sugar oligomers or humins inhibited the selective dehydration of LGA to LGO. For the reaction with H2SO4, the conversion of LGA from bio-oil produced also 1,4:3,6-dianhydro-α-D-glucopyranose (DGP; 21%), a polycyclic anhydrosugar formed by 1,4-acetal, 1,5-acetal, and 3,6-acetal rings. According to the literature [33], the DGP can be derived from acyclic D-glucose by the formation of 1,4 and 3,6 acetal bonds. LGO also can be formed from acyclic D-glucose, but by competitive routes of DGP. For Amberlyst 70, the major products formed were LA (52%), furfural (20%) and LGO (19%). Huang et al. [35] also evaluated the conversion of LGA from bio-oil using Amberlyst 70, but they observed no difference compared to the result obtained for pure LGA. Despite the same LGA/Amberlyst 70 ratio (0.8 w/w) used in our experiments, other conditions differ from those used in the present work and perhaps this was the cause of the different catalytic performance of Amberlyst 70 (solvent= DMSO, initial [LGA] = 0.08 M, in-situ water removal (N2 = 200 mL/min), temperature = 160 °C). The authors suggested that the type of solvent and the in situ water removal during the reaction were key elements to maintain the maximum LGO yield while avoiding humins formation. 3.2.4 Reaction scheme for the LGA conversion Cao et al. [21] and He et al. [22] proposed a reaction mechanism to describe the LGA conversion using THF as a solvent and homogeneous catalysts [21,22]. According to the authors, cellulose is depolymerized to LGA with polar aprotic solvents under pressure. Then, LGA may react by different reaction pathways: (i) LGA dehydration to LGO, which may be polymerized to form dimers, oligomers or humins; (ii) LGA dehydration to HMF that can be converted into levulinic acid and formic acid; (iii) LGA can be hydrated to glucose, which can be further dehydrated to HMF or transformed into furfural by losing carbon (deformylation) or degraded to humins; (iv) LGA degradation with the formation of dimers, oligomers and humins. Cao et al. [21] and He et al. [22] suggested that the main routes for the formation of degradation products (humins) were glucose and LGO oligomerization. But, significant formation of humins was always observed in their experiments even in the presence of only Brønsted acid sites. However, only a few works studied the conversion of LGA into LGO using heterogeneous catalysts in the liquid phase [23–25]. Furthermore, most of these studies used solid acid catalysts containing only Brønsted acid sites: propylsulfonic acid functionalized silica [23]; Amberlyst [24]. Therefore, the role of the different types of acid sites (Lewis and Brønsted acid sites) on the conversion of LGA into LGO could not be determined. The role of the nature of acid sites on different reactions of carbohydrates-derived molecules has been discussed in the literature [34,35]. Weingarten et al. [34] studied the dehydration of xylose to furfural over catalysts with different acid properties (Amberlyst 70, Nafion, HCl, Zr–P, SiO2–Al2O3, HY, WOX/ZrO2, and Al2O3) in water at 160 °C. They reported that the selectivity to furfural depended on the Brønsted to Lewis acid site ratio. Increasing this ratio continuously increased the selectivity to furfural. According to them, both acid sites catalyze the dehydration of xylose to furfural and the reaction of furfural degradation to humins. However, the Lewis acid sites promote the reaction between xylose and furfural to humins, which reduces the formation of furfural. It is important to note that Amberlyst 70 and Nafion, two ion exchange polymer resins containing only Brønsted acid sites, were also tested and they exhibited the same selectivity to furfural as the Zr-P catalyst that has both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. Huang et al. [35] studied the conversion of LGO into HMF and levulinic acid over different solid acid catalysts (zeolites: HZSM5, Y, Beta, Mordenite; Amberlyst 70 and sulfonated activated carbon) in water at 150 °C. Among all catalysts, ZSM5 and Amberlyst 70 exhibited the highest HMF yield, while the other zeolites showed low LGO conversion and HMF yield. These results were attributed to the pore morphology of the zeolites and the presence of only Brønsted acid sites, respectively. The authors discussed the influence of the acid type (Brønsted or Lewis) on the reaction mechanism. According to the authors, the first step is the isomerization of LGO to HMF, followed by its hydration to LA and FA. Furfural could also be formed from LGO. They proposed that LGO, HMF and furfural are precursors of humins (degradation products), which affected the carbon balance. However, their results indicated that the degradation products derived mainly from LGO rather than HMF and furfural. In addition, the higher formation of degradation products in the ZSM5 in comparison to Amberlyst was attributed to the Lewis acid sites present in the zeolite. Amberlyst has only Brønsted acid sites, which reduced the formation of degradation products. To elucidate the reaction mechanism of LGA conversion and the role of different acid sites over these different catalysts, the intermediates molecules (LGO, HMF and glucose) were also used as substrate. Table 2 summarizes the results obtained for each catalyst. It is important to note that all reactions formed substantial amounts of soluble and/or insoluble dark-brown products (humins), resulting in low carbon balance. It indicates that humins should be formed from LGO, HMF and glucose as already reported [35–37]. The TGA analysis of spent WOX/ZrO2 catalyst confirms the presence of carbonaceous compounds on the catalyst surface (Fig. S5). Among the catalysts, H2SO4 exhibited low LGO conversion (27%), producing only humins, which reveals that humins formation from LGO is promoted by the Brønsted acid sites. Both solid acid catalysts (Amberlyst 70, catalyst with only Brønsted acid sites, and WOX/ZrO2, catalyst with both Bronstend and Lewis acid sites) converted LGO to different products. Amberlyst 70 converted LGO to a greater extent (94%) than WOX/ZrO2 (65%), producing HMF, LA and furfural. For WOX/ZrO2 catalyst, HMF and furfural were the only products formed. Therefore, the hydration of HMF to LA only occurred in the presence of a high amount of Bronsted acid sites. When HMF was used as a substrate, LA was the only detectable product formed over all catalysts. However, H2SO4 and Amberlyst 70 exhibited the highest activity for the conversion of HMF to LA, confirming the important role of Bronsted acid sites in promoting this reaction pathway. For the conversion of glucose, Amberlyst 70 favored the production of LA (48%) while HMF (49%) was the main product for WOX/ZrO2. But, the sum of the selectivities to LA and HMF is the same for both catalysts. In the presence of H2SO4, LGO and DGP were the main products formed. In addition, LGA was only detected in the experiment with the homogenous catalyst. This indicates that glucose was dehydrated to DGP and the water formed reacted with glucose to produce LGA that is further dehydrated to LGO. H2SO4 exhibited the highest selectivity to LGO while Amberlyst and WOX/ZrO2 promoted the formation of HMF and LA. Furthermore, fructose was also produced on the WOX/ZrO2 catalyst. In this catalyst, the Lewis acid sites promoted the isomerization of glucose to fructose that is dehydrated to HMF by the Bronsted acid sites. In the case of Amberlyst 70, glucose is preferentially dehydrated to LGA that is further dehydrated to LGO, which is followed by isomerization to HMF. According to Krishna et al. [13], LGO isomerization to HMF is analogous to the glucose isomerization to fructose, involving a transformation from a 6-membered ring to a 5-membered ring. However, Bronsted acid sites promote the LGO isomerization, whereas Lewis acid sites are responsible for glucose isomerization. Taking into account all the results obtained in our work and the mechanism proposed in the literature [21,22], the main reaction pathways for each catalyst are shown in Scheme 1 . The catalysts containing only Lewis acid sites exhibited low LGA conversion (around 15%) with only the formation of humins, whereas LGA reacts over the catalysts with only Bronsted acid sites (H2SO4, Dowex 50wx8 and Amberlyst 70). These results reveal that the reactions of dehydration of LGA to LGO and hydration of LGA to glucose requires Brønsted acid sites. Only LGO and glucose were formed on the homogeneous catalyst. In this case, the dehydration of LGA produces LGO and water, which reacts with LGA to glucose. Therefore, both reactions (dehydration and hydration of LGA) were promoted by the Brønsted acid sites. The solid acid catalysts containing only Brønsted acid sites (Dowex 50wx8, Amberlyst 70) produced mainly LA, FA and HMF. Only small amounts of glucose were detected for both solid acid catalysts. Considering the experiments carried out with LGO and glucose, which demonstrated that the isomerization of LGO to HMF takes place, and glucose isomerization to fructose does not occur, these results suggest that LGA is dehydrated to LGO, followed by rapid isomerization to HMF, which is hydrated to LA. This is confirmed by the experiments carried out at different LGA conversions. The selectivity to LGO strongly decreased while the formation of LA and FA increased, demonstrating that the Bronsted acid sites catalyzed the production of LGO and its isomerization to HMF and hydration to LA and FA. HMF was also the main product formed for the conversion of LGA over t-ZrO2, SOx-ZrO2, WOx-ZrO2, NbOPO4, all catalysts containing Brønsted as well as Lewis acid sites. The experiments at different LGA conversion demonstrated that the selectivity to glucose decreased and the formation of HMF and furfural increased as the LGA conversion increased. The selectivity to LA was low even at high conversion and the selectivity to LGO remained approximately constant. These results suggest that the Bronsted acid sites promoted the conversion of LGA to glucose and in a minor extent to LGO. Glucose was isomerized on the Lewis acid sites to fructose, which was converted to HMF on the Bronsted acid sites. However, the low LA formation shows that the hydration of HMF to LA requires a higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites. Regardless of the catalyst, the carbon balance was low, indicating the formation of humins through the degradation of LGO, HMF and furfural over the Brønsted acid sites [35]. 4 Conclusion LGA conversion depended on the type of acid sites. The catalysts containing only Lewis acid sites exhibited low activity, producing only humins, whereas the ones with only Bronsted acid sites or high amount of these sites were quite active. For the zeolites, the LGA conversion depended also from their pore structure. USY was quite active whereas HZSM5 exhibited low LGA conversion due to its larger pore sizes. The results obtained revealed that product distribution was also strongly affected by the acid properties of the catalysts. Catalysts containing only Bronsted acid sites were selective to LA while those with both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites favored the formation of HMF. LGO was mainly produced by the homogeneous catalyst. The experiments with different molecules and reaction conditions (LGA conversion, temperature and pressure) gave insights into the role of the acid sites on the reaction mechanism of LGA conversion. The reactions of dehydration of LGA to LGO or hydration of glucose requires Brønsted acid sites. This reaction pathway was promoted by the homogeneous catalyst. For the solid acid catalysts containing only Brønsted acid sites, LGO formed undergo isomerization to HMF, which is hydrated to LA. The production of HMF via isomerization of glucose to fructose followed by its dehydration to HMF does not occur because of the absence of Lewis acid sites. For the catalysts containing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, LGA is mainly hydrated to glucose on the Bronsted acid sites. Then, glucose is preferentially isomerized to fructose on the Lewis acid sites, followed by its dehydration to HMF. The low LA formation shows that the hydration of HMF to LA requires a higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites. coredata.dc:description: The effect of the catalytic properties of various types of solid acids, including oxides (ZrO2, SOX/ZrO2, WOX/ZrO2, Nb2O5, NbOPO4, Al2O3, TiO2), silica–aluminas (ZSM5 and USY zeolites) and acidic ion-exchange resins (Amberlyst-70 and Dowex 50wx8) were investigated for liquid-phase levoglucosan (LGA) conversion. H2SO4 was also evaluated as a reference catalyst. The concentration of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the catalysts was measured by FTIR of adsorbed pyridine and titration with NaOH. The catalysts were tested under different reaction conditions (110–170 °C and 30–60 bar of N2) for 1 h using tetrahydrofuran (THF) as solvent. The product distribution obtained from the LGA conversion can be tuned depending on the type of acid site of the catalyst or the reaction conditions used. Catalysts containing only Bronsted acid sites were selective to LA while those with both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites favored the formation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). LGO was mainly produced by the homogeneous catalyst. The USY and HZM5 (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 23) promoted the production of HMF and glucose, respectively. A reaction mechanism was proposed taking into account the acid properties of the catalysts. The reactions of dehydration of LGA to LGO or hydration of glucose requires Brønsted acid sites. Catalysts with only Lewis acid sites produced only humins. For the catalysts containing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, LGA is mainly hydrated to glucose on the Bronsted acid sites. Then, glucose is preferentially isomerized to fructose on the Lewis acid sites, followed by its dehydration to HMF. The low LA formation shows that the hydration of HMF to LA requires a higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydration of levoglucosan to levoglucosenone over solid acid catalysts. Tuning the product distribution by changing the acid properties of the catalysts
